SEARCH
Package org.hd.d.TRVmodel.hg

Class HGTRVHPMModelParameterised

java.lang.Object
org.hd.d.TRVmodel.hg.HGTRVHPMModelParameterised
public final class HGTRVHPMModelParameterised extends Object
Parameterised recreation of the heat-pump / TRV / energy interactions from Heat Geek's page: https://www.heatgeek.com/why-not-to-zone-heat-pumps-or-boilers/ as of ~2023-06.

This is examining if turning down TRVs in unused rooms saves energy or not, as is commonly assumed eg with gas-fired heating.

Many thanks to Heat Geek for making this analysis and explanation available.

This is a simple model, mirroring the page above.

This model is steady-state, ie in temperature equilibrium.

Note that the calculations are all stateless, so could be memoised/cached for any particular set of input parameters.

  • Method Details

    • computeFlowCoP

      public static double computeFlowCoP(double flowC)
      Estimate the CoP for a given flow temperature (C) given the two supplied data points. This does a simple linear fit, which is not perfect but probably adequate.

      Note this is for flow temperature, given the sample manufacturer's data, though the original text uses this interchangeably with mid temperature.

    • computeBungalowHPElectricityDemandW

      public static double computeBungalowHPElectricityDemandW(HGTRVHPMModelParameterised.ModelParameters params, boolean withBSetback)
      Compute the original HG 4-room 'bungalow' heat-pump electricity demand (W); zero or more. The calculation uses constants from HGTRVHPMModel as far as possible, substituting in parameters and new calculation where needed.
      Parameters:
      params - the variable model parameters
      withBSetback - if true, with B rooms set back, else all at same temperature
      Returns:
      demand in watts, finite and non-negative

    • sbAMW

      public static double sbAMW(double HHLsb, double radWnsb, double IWAabHLW)
      Radiator mean water temperature in each A room when B setback (C).
      Parameters:
      HHLsb - whole home heat loss with B rooms setback and given external air temperature (W)
      radWnsb - pre-setback radiator output based on variable external air temperature (W)
      IWFAabHLW - internal wall/floor heat loss/transfer per A room (W)
      Returns:
      (radAsbMW) mean water temperature in each A room when B setback (C)

    • iwHeatLossPerA

      private static double iwHeatLossPerA(HGTRVHPMModelParameterised.ModelParameters params)
      Internal wall heat loss/transfer per A room (HEAT LOSS 1) with A at 'normal' temperature (W). *
      Parameters:
      params - the model parameters; never null

    • iwHeatLossPerA

      private static double iwHeatLossPerA(HGTRVHPMModelParameterised.ModelParameters params, double tempA)
      Internal wall heat loss/transfer per A room (HEAT LOSS 1) (W). This allows an A room temperature other than the initial 'normal' 21C, though it must still be above the B room setback temperature.
      Parameters:
      params - the model parameters; never null
      tempA - the A room temperature in C; no lower than B (and finite)

    • ifHeatLossPerA2Storey

      private static double ifHeatLossPerA2Storey(HGTRVHPMModelParameterised.ModelParameters params)
      Internal floor/ceiling heat loss/transfer per A room (W) for 2-storey detached. Only applies when a B room is directly above or below.

      This is only for a 2-storey detached, so in an ABAB arrangement (with BABA below) each A room will lose each either to a B room below or above (not both). Heat loss in each direction (up or down) is treated as the same.

      Assumes that A room is at 'normal' temperature and B room is at setback temperature.

      Parameters:
      params - model parameters; non-null

    • ifHeatLossPerA2Storey

      private static double ifHeatLossPerA2Storey(HGTRVHPMModelParameterised.ModelParameters params, double tempA)
      Internal floor/ceiling heat loss/transfer per A room (W) for 2-storey detached. Only applies when a B room is directly above or below.

      This is only for a 2-storey detached, so in an ABAB arrangement (with BABA below) each A room will lose each either to a B room below or above (not both). Heat loss in each direction (up or down) is treated as the same.

      Parameters:
      params - model parameters; non-null
      tempA - temperature of A room, must be no lower than B room setback.

    • nsbAMW

      public static double nsbAMW(double radWnsb)
      Compute radiator mean water temperature in each A room when B is NOT set back (C). Extension to heat loss 2 to allow for varying external temperatures.

      This is in fact the MW temperature for all room radiators when there are no setbacks.

      Parameters:
      radWnsb - pre-setback radiator output based on variable external air temperature (W)
      Returns:
      (radAnsbMW) radiator mean water temperature in each A room when B is NOT set back (C)

      public static HGTRVHPMModelParameterised.DemandWithoutAndWithSetback computeBungalowDemandW(HGTRVHPMModelParameterised.ModelParameters params)
      Compute the original HG 4-room 'bungalow' raw heat and heat-pump electricity demand with and without B-room setback (W). The calculation uses constants from HGTRVHPMModel as far as possible, substituting in parameters and new calculation where needed.
      Parameters:
      params - the variable model parameters
      Returns:
      demand in watts, finite and non-negative

      Parameters:

    • computeDetachedDemandW

      public static HGTRVHPMModelParameterised.DemandWithoutAndWithSetback computeDetachedDemandW(HGTRVHPMModelParameterised.ModelParameters params, boolean keepAsBungalow)
      Compute 8-room 'detached' raw heat and heat-pump electricity demand with and without B-room setback (W). The calculation uses constants from HGTRVHPMModel as far as possible, substituting in parameters and new calculation where needed.
      Parameters:
      params - the variable model parameters
      keepAsBungalow - if true, compute as 4-room bungalow to cross-check with original calculation
      Returns:
      demand in watts, finite and non-negative

    • computeSoftATempDemandW

      public static HGTRVHPMModelParameterised.DemandWithoutAndWithSetback computeSoftATempDemandW(HGTRVHPMModelParameterised.ModelParameters params, boolean bungalow, double[] equilibriumTemperature)
      Compute raw heat and heat-pump electricity demand with and without setback, for 'soft' A temperature regulation (W). This lets the A room temperature droop during B-room setback, and does not raise the flow temperature.

      This assumes that:

      • B room temperatures (and A room temperatures) are 'normal' (21C) without setback.
      • B room temperatures are the expected 18C when set back.
      • Flow temperature is pinned during setback to the temperature that maintained A and B rooms at 'normal' temperature without setback, ie as if the flow temperature is entirely driven by external temperature and thus weather compensation.

      Note: this does not allow for the temperature delta across the radiator rising, and thus the mean water (MW) temperature dropping further from the flow temperature, as more heat is drawn by an A room below 'normal' temperature.

      Parameters:
      params - the variable model parameters
      bungalow - if true, compute as 4-room bungalow, else as 8-room detached
      equilibriumTemperature - if not null and not zero length, used to return the A-room equilibrium temperature
      Returns:
      demand in watts, finite and non-negative
